title: Network Analysis Glossary
text:
A graph is a mathematical structure consisting of a set of objects (vertices) and a set of connections (edges) between pairs of these objects. In network analysis, graphs provide the fundamental framework for representing relationships and interactions between entities. Graphs can be directed (edges have direction) or undirected (edges have no inherent direction).
\[
G = {v, e}
\]
where
\[v = [v_1, v_2, ..., v_i, ... v_n]\]
and
\[e = [(v_1, v_2), (v_1, v_i), ..., (v_i, v_j), ..., (v_j, v_n)]\]



Vertices (also called nodes) are the fundamental units or entities in a network. They represent the objects being studied, such as:

People in social networks
Computers in technological networks
Proteins in biological networks
Cities in transportation networks

Each vertex can have attributes (e.g., age, location, type) that provide additional information about the entity it represents.



Edges (also called links or ties) represent the connections or relationships between vertices. They encode the interactions, associations, or dependencies between entities in the network. Edges can have various properties:

Direction (directed vs.¬†undirected)
Weight (strength of connection)
Type (multiple relationship types)
Temporal information (when the connection exists)




A network relationship defines the nature of connections between entities in a network. These relationships determine:

What constitutes a connection (e.g., friendship, communication, transaction)
How connections are measured or identified
Whether relationships are symmetric or asymmetric
The meaning and interpretation of network patterns

title: Network Analysis Glossary
text:
Network Types

One-mode vs Two-mode Networks

One-mode Networks
One-mode networks (also called unipartite networks) contain only one type of vertex. All connections occur between vertices of the same type. Examples include:

Friendship networks (people connected to people)
Citation networks (papers citing papers)
Trade networks (countries trading with countries)

Here‚Äôs an example of creating a one-mode network visualization concerning a collaboration network among five co-workers:





Example of a one-mode collaboration network showing connections between individuals






Directed Vs Undirected Networks
Directed networks (also called digraphs) have edges with a specific direction, indicating asymmetric relationships where the connection flows from one vertex to another. Examples include:

Email networks (sender ‚Üí receiver)
Citation networks (citing paper ‚Üí cited paper)

Food webs (predator ‚Üí prey)
Twitter follower networks (follower ‚Üí followed)

Here‚Äôs an example of a directed network:





Directed Email Communication Network




Undirected networks have edges without direction, representing symmetric relationships where connections are mutual. Examples include:

Friendship networks (mutual friendships)
Co-authorship networks (collaborations)
Infrastructure networks (roads, power grids)
Protein interaction networks

The choice between directed and undirected representation depends on whether the relationship being modeled is inherently asymmetric or symmetric.


Two-mode Networks
Two-mode networks (also called bipartite networks) contain two distinct types of vertices, and edges only connect vertices of different types. Examples include:

Actor-movie networks (actors connected to movies they appear in)
Author-paper networks (authors connected to papers they wrote)
Customer-product networks (customers connected to products they purchased)

Here‚Äôs an example of a two-mode purchasing network:





Two-Mode Customer-Product Purchasing Network







Signed Networks
Signed networks are networks where edges carry positive or negative values, representing different types of relationships:

Positive edges: friendship, alliance, cooperation
Negative edges: animosity, conflict, competition

Signed networks are particularly useful for studying:

Social balance theory
Coalition formation
Conflict dynamics
Opinion polarization

Here‚Äôs an example of a signed social network like cooperative Vs. competitive ties among co-workers:





Signed Social Network with Positive and Negative Relationships






Weighted vs Unweighted Networks

Weighted Networks
Weighted networks have edges with numerical values (weights) representing the strength, frequency, or capacity of connections. Examples include:

Communication networks (number of messages exchanged)
Transportation networks (traffic volume or distance)
Neural networks (synaptic strength)
Financial networks (transaction amounts)

Here‚Äôs an example of a weighted communication network:





Weighted Communication Network (Edge Width = Message Volume)






Unweighted Networks
Unweighted networks (also called binary networks) have edges that simply indicate the presence or absence of a connection. All edges are treated equally, focusing on the topology rather than connection strength. These are simpler to analyze but may lose important information about relationship intensity.

title: Network Analysis Glossary
text:
Network Substructures

Dyads
A dyad is the simplest possible network substructure, consisting of a pair of vertices and the possible edge(s) between them. In directed networks, dyads can be classified as:

Null dyad: no connection in either direction
Asymmetric dyad: connection in one direction only
Mutual/Reciprocal dyad: connections in both directions

Dyadic analysis examines pairwise relationships and forms the foundation for understanding reciprocity and basic network patterns.
Here‚Äôs a visualization showing a dyad within a larger network:





Network with Emphasized Dyad (Alice-Bob)






Triads
A triad consists of three vertices and the possible edges among them. Triads are fundamental for understanding:

Transitivity (‚Äúfriend of a friend‚Äù patterns)
Structural balance
Clustering tendencies
Local network motifs

Here‚Äôs a visualization showing a triad within a larger network:





Network with Emphasized Triad (Alice-Bob-Charlie)




We will deal with these in weeks 4 and 5.

Community detection is a fundamental technique in network analysis used to identify groups of nodes that are more densely connected to each other than to the rest of the network. In a business context, these ‚Äúcommunities‚Äù often represent meaningful substructures:

Organizational Analytics: Identifying informal teams or silos within a company.
Marketing: Segmenting customers based on purchasing behavior or social influence.
Fraud Detection: Uncovering rings of colluding actors.
Supply Chain: Detecting tightly integrated clusters of suppliers.

This tutorial provides a comprehensive guide to detecting and analyzing these cohesive subgroups using R. We will move beyond simple execution to understand the mechanisms behind different algorithms, how to compare their results, and how to validate the stability of the communities found.


By the end of this tutorial, you will be able to:

Evaluate the quality of partitions using modularity and density metrics.
Compare results across methods to identify robust community structures.
Visualize communities effectively to communicate insights.

text:
3.1 Method 1: Louvain Algorithm
The Louvain algorithm is one of the most popular methods for community detection due to its efficiency and ability to handle large networks (up to millions of nodes).

3.1.1 How it works
It is a hierarchical, greedy algorithm that optimizes modularity (\(Q\)). 1. Local Moving: Each node is moved to the community of its neighbors that yields the largest increase in modularity. 2. Aggregation: A new network is built where nodes are the communities found in step 1. 3. Repeat: Steps 1 and 2 are repeated until no further modularity increase is possible.
Pros: Very fast; good quality partitions. Cons: Can fail to detect small communities in very large networks (resolution limit).

# Detect communities using Louvain
louvain_comm <- cluster_louvain(karate)

# Summary statistics

title: Community Detection in R
text:
3.2 Method 2: Edge Betweenness
The Girvan-Newman (Edge Betweenness) algorithm is a divisive method based on the concept of ‚Äúbridges‚Äù in a network.

3.2.1 How it works
It relies on edge betweenness centrality‚Äîthe number of shortest paths passing through an edge. Edges connecting different communities act as bottlenecks and have high betweenness. 1. Calculate betweenness for all edges. 2. Remove the edge with the highest betweenness. 3. Recalculate betweenness for remaining edges. 4. Repeat until no edges remain or a target number of communities is reached.
Pros: Intuitively appealing; often very accurate for small networks. Cons: Computationally expensive (\(O(N^3)\)); not suitable for large graphs (>1000 nodes).

# Detect communities using edge betweenness
eb_comm <- cluster_edge_betweenness(karate)

cat("Number of communities:", length(eb_comm), "\n")

title: Community Detection in R
text:
3.3 Method 3: Walktrap
The Walktrap algorithm exploits the tendency of random walks to get ‚Äútrapped‚Äù within densely connected parts of a graph.

3.3.1 How it works
It defines a distance between nodes based on random walks. If two nodes are in the same community, the probability of getting from one to the other in a random walk is high. The algorithm agglomeratively merges nodes/communities that minimize the squared distance between them.
Pros: robust; works well on dense subgraphs. Cons: Slower than Louvain; complexity is approx \(O(N^2 \log N)\).

walktrap_comm <- cluster_walktrap(karate)

text:
3.4 Method 4: Leading Eigenvector (Spectral)
Spectral clustering methods use the linear algebra properties of the graph to find partitions.

3.4.1 How it works
This specific implementation calculates the leading eigenvector of the modularity matrix. The signs of the elements in this eigenvector can be used to split the network into two communities. This process is repeated recursively to subdivide the network further.
Pros: Theoretically well-grounded; effective for identifying core structures. Cons: Can be slower; sometimes struggles with very small or very disparate community sizes.

3.5 Method 5: Fast Greedy
The Fast Greedy (Clauset-Newman-Moore) algorithm is a hierarchical agglomerative approach designed for speed.

3.5.1 How it works
It starts with every node in its own community. At each step, it merges the pair of communities that results in the largest increase in modularity. It uses sophisticated data structures to do this efficiently.
Pros: Fast; good for large networks. Cons: Greedy nature means it can get stuck in local optima; often produces ‚Äúmega-communities‚Äù by merging smaller ones too early.

# Function to calculate normalized mutual information
calculate_nmi <- function(comm1, comm2) {
  compare(comm1, comm2, method = "nmi")
}

  Louvain = louvain_comm,
  EdgeBet = eb_comm,
  Walktrap = walktrap_comm,
  Spectral = spectral_comm,
  FastGreedy = fg_comm
)

rownames(nmi_matrix) <- colnames(nmi_matrix) <- names(methods_list)

for(i in 1:5) {
  for(j in 1:5) {
    nmi_matrix[i,j] <- calculate_nmi(methods_list[[i]], methods_list[[j]])
  }
}

# Display as heatmap

title: Community Detection in R
text:
5.1 Within vs.¬†Between Community Density
A ‚Äúgood‚Äù community should have: 1. High internal density: Nodes within the community are tightly connected. 2. Low external density: Few connections exist between different communities.
We can quantify this by calculating the ratio of internal to external density. A high ratio (>10 or >100) indicates very well-defined groups.

# Function to calculate within and between community density
analyze_density <- function(graph, communities) {
  membership <- membership(communities)
  n_comm <- max(membership)
  
  within_density <- numeric(n_comm)
  
  for(i in 1:n_comm) {
    subgraph <- induced_subgraph(graph, which(membership == i))
    within_density[i] <- edge_density(subgraph)
  }
  
  # Calculate between community density
  total_possible <- vcount(graph) * (vcount(graph) - 1) / 2
  within_nodes <- sapply(1:n_comm, function(i) sum(membership == i))
  within_possible <- sum(within_nodes * (within_nodes - 1) / 2)
  between_possible <- total_possible - within_possible
  
  between_edges <- ecount(graph) - 
    sum(sapply(1:n_comm, function(i) {
      ecount(induced_subgraph(graph, which(membership == i)))
    }))
  
  between_density <- between_edges / between_possible
  
  list(
    within_mean = mean(within_density),
    within_sd = sd(within_density),
    between = between_density,
    ratio = mean(within_density) / between_density
  )
}

# Analyze Louvain communities
density_stats <- analyze_density(karate, louvain_comm)

cat("Within-community density (mean):", round(density_stats$within_mean, 3), "\n")

Within-community density (mean): 0.451 

cat("Between-community density:", round(density_stats$between, 3), "\n")

Between-community density: 0.051 

cat("Ratio (within/between):", round(density_stats$ratio, 2), "\n")

Ratio (within/between): 8.91

3.1 Method 1: Greedy Modularity (Clauset-Newman-Moore)
The Greedy Modularity algorithm (often called Clauset-Newman-Moore) is the standard hierarchical agglomerative method in NetworkX.

3.1.1 How it works

Start with each node in its own community.
Repeatedly join the pair of communities that produces the largest increase in modularity (\(Q\)).
Stop when no further increase is possible.

Pros: Good balance of speed and quality; deterministic (always gives the same result). Cons: Can be slower than Louvain on very large graphs; prone to the ‚Äúresolution limit‚Äù (merging small communities).

3.2 Method 2: Label Propagation
Label Propagation is a unique algorithm because it doesn‚Äôt optimize a global metric like modularity. Instead, it uses a local voting mechanism.

3.2.1 How it works

Every node is initialized with a unique label.
In each iteration, nodes update their label to the one most frequent among their neighbors (majority vote).
Ties are broken randomly.
The process stops when every node has the majority label of its neighbors.

Pros: Extremely fast (near linear time); no parameters to tune. Cons: Non-deterministic (different runs give different results); can get stuck in oscillations; doesn‚Äôt guarantee a high modularity score.

3.3 Method 3: Girvan-Newman (Edge Betweenness)
The Girvan-Newman algorithm is a ‚Äúdivisive‚Äù method that focuses on removing bridges between communities.

3.3.1 How it works
It iteratively removes the edge with the highest edge betweenness centrality. * Betweenness: The number of shortest paths passing through an edge. * Logic: Edges connecting communities act as bottlenecks, so they have high betweenness.
This method produces a dendrogram (hierarchy). We can stop at any level to get a specific number of communities.
Pros: Very accurate for small networks; reveals hierarchical structure. Cons: Very slow (\(O(N^3)\)); impractical for networks with >500 nodes.

title: Role and Position Analysis in R
text:
This tutorial demonstrates how to analyze roles and positions in networks using R. Unlike community detection, which looks for cohesive subgroups (cliques, clusters), role analysis seeks to identify actors who behave similarly, even if they are not connected to each other. For example, two teachers in different schools may never interact, but they occupy the same ‚Äòrole‚Äô because they have similar relationships with students, principals, and parents.
We will explore structural equivalence, implement the classic CONCOR algorithm, perform blockmodeling, and create image matrices to uncover the underlying role structure of networks.


By the end of this tutorial, you will be able to:

Understand different concepts of structural equivalence
Compute similarity measures between actors based on tie patterns
Implement the CONCOR algorithm for blockmodeling
Perform hierarchical clustering of tie profiles
Create and interpret blockmodels and image matrices
Visualize role structures in networks
Assess the quality of blockmodel fits

Role and Position Analysis in R
text:
2.1 Concepts
Structural Equivalence is the most stringent definition of position. Two actors are structurally equivalent if they have identical ties to and from the exact same other actors. They are perfectly substitutable in the network structure.
In practice, perfect equivalence is rare. We look for approximate equivalence‚Äîactors who have similar patterns of ties.
There are other forms of equivalence, such as:

Structural equivalence: Actors have identical ties to the same others.
Regular equivalence: Actors have ties to others who are themselves equivalent (e.g., two doctors are equivalent because they both treat patients, even if they treat different patients).

This tutorial focuses on structural equivalence, which is the foundation of classical blockmodeling.

text:
3.1 Correlation-Based Similarity
One common approach is to calculate the Pearson correlation between the tie profiles (rows/columns of the adjacency matrix) of pairs of actors.

High positive correlation (+1): Actors have very similar tie patterns.
High negative correlation (-1): Actors have opposite tie patterns.
Correlation focuses on the pattern or shape of ties, normalizing for the total number of ties.


# Calculate structural equivalence using correlation
# For directed networks, we consider both in-ties and out-ties

# Custom function for structural equivalence
compute_structural_equiv <- function(adj_mat) {
  n <- nrow(adj_mat)
  sim_mat <- matrix(0, n, n)
  
  # Combine row and column vectors for each node
  for(i in 1:n) {
    for(j in 1:n) {
      # Correlation between tie profiles
      profile_i <- c(adj_mat[i,], adj_mat[,i])
      profile_j <- c(adj_mat[j,], adj_mat[,j])
      sim_mat[i,j] <- cor(profile_i, profile_j)
    }
  }
  
  rownames(sim_mat) <- colnames(sim_mat) <- rownames(adj_mat)
  return(sim_mat)
}

3.2 Euclidean Distance
Another approach uses Euclidean distance between tie profiles.

Measures the geometric distance between actors in the multidimensional space defined by their ties.
Unlike correlation, it is sensitive to the volume (number) of ties. Two actors might have the same pattern, but if one has twice as many ties, they will be distant in Euclidean space but highly correlated.


# Compute Euclidean distance
compute_euclidean_dist <- function(adj_mat) {
  n <- nrow(adj_mat)
  dist_mat <- matrix(0, n, n)
  
  for(i in 1:n) {
    for(j in 1:n) {
      profile_i <- c(adj_mat[i,], adj_mat[,i])
      profile_j <- c(adj_mat[j,], adj_mat[,j])
      dist_mat[i,j] <- sqrt(sum((profile_i - profile_j)^2))
    }
  }
  
  rownames(dist_mat) <- colnames(dist_mat) <- rownames(adj_mat)
  return(dist_mat)
}

5.1 Implementing CONCOR

# Perform CONCOR using custom implementation
# Simplified CONCOR algorithm
concor_simple <- function(adj_mat, max_iter = 25) {
  # Compute initial correlation matrix
  sim_mat <- compute_structural_equiv(adj_mat)
  
  # Iteratively correlate
  for(iter in 1:max_iter) {
    old_sim <- sim_mat
    sim_mat <- cor(sim_mat)
    
    # Check for convergence
    if(max(abs(sim_mat - old_sim)) < 0.001) break
  }
  
  # Convert to distance and cluster  
  dist_mat <- as.dist(1 - sim_mat)
  hc <- hclust(dist_mat, method = "complete")
  return(hc)
}

7.1 Compute Image Matrix

# Function to create image matrix
create_image_matrix <- function(adj_matrix, positions, alpha = 0.5) {
  n_positions <- max(positions)
  image_mat <- matrix(0, nrow = n_positions, ncol = n_positions)
  
  for(i in 1:n_positions) {
    for(j in 1:n_positions) {
      # Get actors in positions i and j
      actors_i <- which(positions == i)
      actors_j <- which(positions == j)
      
      # Extract block
      block <- adj_matrix[actors_i, actors_j, drop = FALSE]
      
      # Calculate density
      block_density <- sum(block) / length(block)
      
      # Set image based on alpha threshold
      image_mat[i, j] <- ifelse(block_density >= alpha, 1, 0)
    }
  }
  
  rownames(image_mat) <- colnames(image_mat) <- paste0("Pos", 1:n_positions)
  return(image_mat)
}

# Reconstruct network from blockmodel
reconstruct_from_blocks <- function(image_mat, positions) {

      pos_j <- positions[j]

title: Week 7
text:
Conceptual Foundations

Social Cohesion vs.¬†Structural Equivalence
These two approaches to network structure trace back to fundamental concepts in sociology:
Durkheim‚Äôs Mechanical vs.¬†Organic Solidarity

Mechanical solidarity: Integration through similarity and shared attributes. Maps onto communities - people cluster with those like themselves (homophily).
Organic solidarity: Integration through differentiation and interdependence. Maps onto positions - people occupy specialized roles in a division of labor.

Implications for Network Analysis
Communities and positions represent orthogonal dimensions of social structure. A network can have strong community structure (high modularity) AND clear positional structure (distinct roles), weak on both dimensions, or strong on one but not the other.


The Strength of Weak Ties
Granovetter‚Äôs (1973) seminal insight: weak ties (acquaintances) provide access to diverse information that strong ties (close friends) cannot, because strong ties tend to cluster in the same communities.


Code
# Demonstrate the strength of weak ties
library(igraph)
library(ggplot2)

set.seed(123)

# Create a network with two communities connected by weak ties
g1 <- make_full_graph(10)  # Community 1 (strong ties)
g2 <- make_full_graph(10)  # Community 2 (strong ties)

# Combine communities
g <- disjoint_union(g1, g2)

# Add a few weak ties bridging communities (lower weight)
g <- add_edges(g, c(5, 15, 7, 17, 2, 12))

# Set edge weights: strong ties = 5, weak ties = 1
E(g)$weight <- 5
E(g)$weight[tail(seq_len(ecount(g)), 3)] <- 1

# Calculate betweenness - weak ties score high!
btw <- edge_betweenness(g)
E(g)$color <- ifelse(E(g)$weight == 1, "red", "gray80")
E(g)$width <- ifelse(E(g)$weight == 1, 3, 1)

plot(g, 
     vertex.size = 8,
     vertex.label = NA,
     edge.color = E(g)$color,
     edge.width = E(g)$width,
     main = "Weak Ties (red) Bridge Communities")

# Information reach simulation
reach_via_strong <- mean(distances(g, mode = "all")[1:10, 1:10])
reach_via_weak <- mean(distances(g, mode = "all"))

cat("Average path within community:", round(reach_via_strong, 2), "\n")
cat("Average path across network:", round(reach_via_weak, 2), "\n")
cat("Weak ties reduce path length by:", 
    round((reach_via_strong - reach_via_weak) / reach_via_strong * 100, 1), "%\n")


Key insight: The three weak ties connecting the communities are bottlenecks for information flow. Removing them would double the average path length.


Small-World Networks
Watts & Strogatz (1998) showed that many real networks combine:

High clustering (dense local neighborhoods)
Short average path lengths (few steps between any two nodes)

This combination creates networks that are ‚Äúsmall worlds‚Äù - highly clustered yet globally connected.


Code
library(igraph)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)

set.seed(42)

# Create three network types
n <- 100  # number of nodes
k <- 4    # mean degree

# 1. Regular lattice ring (high clustering, high path length)
regular <- make_ring(n)
regular <- connect.neighborhood(regular, k/2)

# 2. Random network (low clustering, low path length)
random <- sample_gnm(n, ecount(regular))

# 3. Small-world (high clustering, low path length)
small_world <- watts.strogatz.game(1, n, k/2, 0.1)  # 10% rewiring

# Calculate metrics
metrics <- data.frame(
  Network = c("Regular", "Random", "Small-World"),
  Clustering = c(
    transitivity(regular, type = "average"),
    transitivity(random, type = "average"),
    transitivity(small_world, type = "average")
  ),
  AvgPathLength = c(
    mean_distance(regular),
    mean_distance(random),
    mean_distance(small_world)
  )
)

# Visualize metrics
metrics_long <- metrics %>%
  tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = c(Clustering, AvgPathLength),
                      names_to = "Metric", values_to = "Value")

ggplot(metrics_long, aes(x = Network, y = Value, fill = Network)) +
  geom_col() +
  facet_wrap(~Metric, scales = "free_y") +
  labs(title = "Small-World Networks Combine High Clustering + Short Paths",
       y = "Value") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

# Show the small-world phenomenon numerically
cat("The Small-World Advantage:\n")
cat("Clustering similar to regular network:", 
    round(metrics$Clustering[3] / metrics$Clustering[1], 2), "√ó\n")
cat("Path length similar to random network:", 
    round(metrics$AvgPathLength[3] / metrics$AvgPathLength[2], 2), "√ó\n")


Why it matters: Small-world structure facilitates both local cohesion (communities) and global reach (short paths). This is observed in social networks, neural networks, power grids, and the World Wide Web.


Network Cohesion: Multiple Definitions
Cohesion is intuitive but has multiple formal definitions:








Definition
Criterion
Algorithm Example




Clique-based
Complete subgraphs
K-clique communities


Density-based
High internal edge density
Modularity optimization


Connectivity-based
Multiple independent paths
K-component analysis


Flow-based
Resource circulation
Random walk methods (Walktrap)



Different definitions capture different aspects of ‚Äúgroupness‚Äù and may disagree on boundaries. This is a feature, not a bug - cohesion is multidimensional.


Code
library(igraph)

# Create a network with two clear communities
karate <- make_graph("Zachary")

# Apply different community detection methods
louvain <- cluster_louvain(karate)        # Modularity-based
walktrap <- cluster_walktrap(karate)      # Random walk-based
fastgreedy <- cluster_fast_greedy(karate) # Hierarchical modularity

# Compare results
cat("Number of communities detected:\n")
cat("  Louvain (density):", length(louvain), "\n")
cat("  Walktrap (flow):", length(walktrap), "\n")
cat("  Fast Greedy (modularity):", length(fastgreedy), "\n")

cat("\nModularity scores:\n")
cat("  Louvain:", round(modularity(louvain), 3), "\n")
cat("  Walktrap:", round(modularity(walktrap), 3), "\n")
cat("  Fast Greedy:", round(modularity(fastgreedy), 3), "\n")

# Agreement between methods
nmi <- compare(louvain, walktrap, method = "nmi")
cat("\nAgreement (NMI) between Louvain and Walktrap:", round(nmi, 3), "\n")

title: Week 7
text:
Communities in Practice

Quick Start: Detecting Communities
Let‚Äôs start with the canonical example - Zachary‚Äôs Karate Club:


Code
library(igraph)
library(ggplot2)

# Load karate club network
karate <- make_graph("Zachary")

# Detect communities (Louvain algorithm)
communities <- cluster_louvain(karate)

# Visualize
set.seed(42)
plot(communities, karate,
     vertex.size = 12,
     vertex.label.cex = 0.7,
     edge.color = "gray80",
     main = paste0("Karate Club Communities\nModularity = ", 
                   round(modularity(communities), 3)))

# Summary
cat("Number of communities:", length(communities), "\n")
cat("Community sizes:", sizes(communities), "\n")
cat("Modularity:", round(modularity(communities), 3), "\n")


What we see: The algorithm correctly identifies the two factions that emerged when the club split - validating that community detection captures real social divisions.


Understanding Modularity
Modularity measures whether a partition has more within-group edges than expected by chance. Formally:
\[Q = \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{ij} \left[A_{ij} - \frac{k_i k_j}{2m}\right] \delta(c_i, c_j)\]
Where: - \(A_{ij}\) = observed edge between \(i\) and \(j\) - \(\frac{k_i k_j}{2m}\) = expected edges under random null model - \(\delta(c_i, c_j)\) = 1 if nodes in same community, 0 otherwise
Intuition: High modularity means many within-community edges and few between-community edges, relative to a random baseline.


Code
library(igraph)

# Create a network with obvious community structure
g <- make_full_graph(20) %du% make_full_graph(20)  # Two cliques
g <- add_edges(g, c(10, 30, 15, 25))  # Add 2 bridge edges

# Modularity of the "true" partition
true_membership <- c(rep(1, 20), rep(2, 20))
true_comm <- make_clusters(g, membership = true_membership)
Q_true <- modularity(g, true_membership)

# Modularity of a random partition
random_membership <- sample(1:2, 40, replace = TRUE)
Q_random <- modularity(g, random_membership)

# Modularity of algorithm-detected partition
louvain_comm <- cluster_louvain(g)
Q_louvain <- modularity(louvain_comm)

# Compare
comparison <- data.frame(
  Partition = c("True Communities", "Random", "Louvain"),
  Modularity = c(Q_true, Q_random, Q_louvain)
)

print(comparison)

ggplot(comparison, aes(x = reorder(Partition, Modularity), y = Modularity)) +
  geom_col(fill = "steelblue", alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(Modularity, 3)), vjust = -0.5) +
  ylim(0, 1) +
  labs(title = "Modularity Distinguishes Community Structure",
       x = "Partition Type",
       y = "Modularity (Q)") +
  theme_minimal()


Key takeaway: Modularity near 0.3-0.7 suggests meaningful community structure. Values near 0 indicate no more structure than random. Values > 0.7 are rare and indicate very strong divisions.


Real Network Example: Scientific Collaboration
Let‚Äôs analyze a co-authorship network from published research papers:


Code
library(igraph)
library(dplyr)

# Simulate a realistic collaboration network
# (In practice, load this from bibliometric data)
set.seed(123)

# Create a network with research field communities
n_fields <- 4
authors_per_field <- 25
total_authors <- n_fields * authors_per_field

# Generate field membership
field <- rep(1:n_fields, each = authors_per_field)

# Create edges: high probability within field, low between
g <- make_empty_graph(n = total_authors, directed = FALSE)

# Within-field collaboration (dense)
for(f in 1:n_fields) {
  authors_in_field <- which(field == f)
  # 30% of possible within-field edges
  g <- add_edges(g, 
                 t(combn(sample(authors_in_field, 15), 2)))
}

# Cross-field collaboration (sparse)
for(i in 1:20) {
  cross_edge <- sample(1:total_authors, 2)
  if(field[cross_edge[1]] != field[cross_edge[2]]) {
    g <- add_edges(g, cross_edge)
  }
}

# Detect communities
louvain <- cluster_louvain(g)
walktrap <- cluster_walktrap(g)
leiden <- cluster_leiden(g)

# Compare detected vs. true communities
cat("True number of fields:", n_fields, "\n")
cat("Detected communities:\n")
cat("  Louvain:", length(louvain), "\n")
cat("  Walktrap:", length(walktrap), "\n")
cat("  Leiden:", length(leiden), "\n")

cat("\nModularity scores:\n")
cat("  Louvain:", round(modularity(louvain), 3), "\n")
cat("  Walktrap:", round(modularity(walktrap), 3), "\n")
cat("  Leiden:", round(modularity(leiden), 3), "\n")

# How well does detection match true fields?
ari_louvain <- compare(field, membership(louvain), method = "adjusted.rand")
cat("\nAdjusted Rand Index (Louvain vs. True):", round(ari_louvain, 3), "\n")

# Visualize
set.seed(42)
plot(louvain, g,
     vertex.size = 5,
     vertex.label = NA,
     edge.color = "gray90",
     main = "Detected Research Communities")


Interpretation: High ARI (> 0.7) indicates the algorithm successfully recovers disciplinary boundaries. Modularity > 0.4 confirms that co-authorship is structured by research fields.


Comparing Methods: Which Algorithm?
Different algorithms optimize different objectives:



Algorithm
Objective
Speed
Resolution




Louvain
Modularity
Fast
Single-scale


Leiden
Modularity + quality
Fast
Single-scale


Walktrap
Random walk distance
Medium
Multi-scale


Edge Betweenness
Structural bridges
Slow
Hierarchical


Label Propagation
Local information
Very fast
Unstable





Code
library(igraph)
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)

# Use the karate club for comparison
karate <- make_graph("Zachary")

# Apply multiple methods
methods <- list(
  Louvain = cluster_louvain(karate),
  Leiden = cluster_leiden(karate),
  Walktrap = cluster_walktrap(karate),
  EdgeBet = cluster_edge_betweenness(karate),
  FastGreedy = cluster_fast_greedy(karate),
  LabelProp = cluster_label_prop(karate)
)

# Extract metrics
results <- data.frame(
  Method = names(methods),
  Communities = sapply(methods, length),
  Modularity = sapply(methods, modularity),
  stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)

# Visualize comparison
p1 <- ggplot(results, aes(x = reorder(Method, Modularity), y = Modularity)) +
  geom_col(fill = "coral", alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(Modularity, 3)), hjust = -0.2) +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(title = "Modularity by Method",
       x = "", y = "Modularity") +
  theme_minimal()

p2 <- ggplot(results, aes(x = reorder(Method, Communities), y = Communities)) +
  geom_col(fill = "steelblue", alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_text(aes(label = Communities), vjust = -0.5) +
  labs(title = "Number of Communities",
       x = "Method", y = "Count") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

library(patchwork)
p1 / p2


Recommendation: Start with Louvain or Leiden (fast, robust). Use Walktrap for multi-scale structure. Use Edge Betweenness only for hierarchical analysis on small networks (< 1000 nodes).


Resolution Parameter Exploration
Many algorithms have a resolution parameter controlling granularity:


Code
library(igraph)
library(ggplot2)

karate <- make_graph("Zachary")

# Sweep resolution from 0.5 to 2.0
resolutions <- seq(0.5, 2.0, by = 0.1)
results <- data.frame(
  resolution = numeric(),
  n_communities = numeric(),
  modularity = numeric()
)

for (res in resolutions) {
  comm <- cluster_louvain(karate, resolution = res)
  results <- rbind(results, data.frame(
    resolution = res,
    n_communities = length(comm),
    modularity = modularity(comm)
  ))
}

# Plot results
p1 <- ggplot(results, aes(x = resolution, y = n_communities)) +
  geom_line(color = "steelblue", size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(color = "steelblue", size = 2) +
  labs(title = "Resolution Controls Granularity",
       x = "Resolution Parameter",
       y = "Number of Communities") +
  theme_minimal()

p2 <- ggplot(results, aes(x = resolution, y = modularity)) +
  geom_line(color = "coral", size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(color = "coral", size = 2) +
  labs(title = "Modularity vs. Resolution",
       x = "Resolution Parameter",
       y = "Modularity") +
  theme_minimal()

library(patchwork)
p1 + p2

cat("Optimal resolution (max modularity):", 
    results$resolution[which.max(results$modularity)], "\n")


Practical tip: Resolution = 1.0 is the default. Higher values (> 1.0) prefer more, smaller communities. Lower values (< 1.0) prefer fewer, larger communities. Choose based on your substantive question.

title: Week 7
text:
Roles and Positions in Practice

Quick Start: Structural Equivalence
Two nodes are structurally equivalent if they have identical ties to all other nodes. In practice, we look for approximate equivalence - nodes with similar connection patterns occupy the same position.


Code
library(igraph)
library(sna)

# Create a simple advice network (directed)
set.seed(42)
g <- sample_pa(20, directed = TRUE)

# Calculate structural equivalence using correlation
adj_matrix <- as.matrix(as_adjacency_matrix(g))
 
# Correlation-based equivalence
equivalence <- cor(t(adj_matrix))  # Correlate row profiles
diag(equivalence) <- 0  # Remove self-similarity

# Hierarchical clustering to find positions
dist_matrix <- as.dist(1 - equivalence)  # Convert correlation to distance
hc <- hclust(dist_matrix, method = "complete")

# Cut dendrogram to get positions
n_positions <- 4
positions <- cutree(hc, k = n_positions)

# Visualize positions
plot(hc, main = "Hierarchical Clustering of Positions",
     xlab = "Node", ylab = "Dissimilarity")
rect.hclust(hc, k = n_positions, border = "red")

cat("Position assignment:\n")
print(table(positions))


What we see: Nodes cluster into positions based on who they advise and who advises them, independent of direct connections to each other.


Understanding Equivalence Types
There are several ways to measure structural similarity:








Type
Definition
Use Case




Structural Equivalence
Identical ties to same alters
Substitutable roles (competitors)


Regular Equivalence
Similar types of ties
Hierarchical positions (all managers)


Automorphic Equivalence
Topologically identical
Perfect symmetry





Code
library(igraph)

# Create a network illustrating different equivalence types
g <- graph_from_literal(
  Boss1 -+ Worker1A, Boss1 -+ Worker1B,
  Boss2 -+ Worker2A, Boss2 -+ Worker2B,
  TopBoss -+ Boss1, TopBoss -+ Boss2
)

# Visualize
set.seed(42)
V(g)$color <- c("red", "red", "lightblue", "lightblue",
                "lightblue", "lightblue", "gold")
plot(g, 
     vertex.size = 25,
     vertex.label.cex = 0.7,
     edge.arrow.size = 0.5,
     layout = layout_as_tree(g, root = 7),
     main = "Hierarchical Organization")

cat("Regular equivalence examples:\n")
cat("  Boss1 and Boss2: Both supervise workers\n")
cat("  Worker1A, Worker1B, Worker2A, Worker2B: All supervised\n\n")

cat("Structural equivalence examples:\n")
cat("  Worker1A and Worker1B: Identical ties (both supervised by Boss1)\n")
cat("  Worker2A and Worker2B: Identical ties (both supervised by Boss2)\n")


Key distinction: - Structural equivalence: Worker1A and Worker1B are substitutable - Regular equivalence: All workers play the same role, even if supervised by different bosses


Blockmodeling: Image Matrices
A blockmodel reduces a network to interactions between positions, not individuals. The image matrix shows which positions connect to which.


Code
library(igraph)
library(blockmodeling)

# Create an organizational communication network
set.seed(123)
n <- 30

# Three positions: senior (1-10), mid (11-20), junior (21-30)
true_positions <- c(rep(1, 10), rep(2, 10), rep(3, 10))

# Generate edges based on positions
# Senior -> all (advice giving)
# Mid -> Junior (supervision)
# Junior -> Mid (reporting)
# Within-group communication

g <- make_empty_graph(n, directed = TRUE)

# Senior advises everyone
for(i in 1:10) {
  targets <- sample((1:n)[-i], 8)
  g <- add_edges(g, rbind(i, targets))
}

# Mid advises juniors
for(i in 11:20) {
  targets <- sample(21:30, 4)
  g <- add_edges(g, rbind(i, targets))
}

# Juniors report to mid
for(i in 21:30) {
  targets <- sample(11:20, 2)
  g <- add_edges(g, rbind(i, targets))
}

# Some within-group ties
for(pos in 1:3) {
  idx <- which(true_positions == pos)
  g <- add_edges(g, t(combn(sample(idx, 4), 2)))
}

# Create blockmodel
adj <- as.matrix(as_adjacency_matrix(g))

# Image matrix: binary representation of block densities
image_matrix <- matrix(0, nrow = 3, ncol = 3)
for(i in 1:3) {
  for(j in 1:3) {
    block <- adj[true_positions == i, true_positions == j]
    density <- mean(block)
    image_matrix[i, j] <- ifelse(density > 0.1, 1, 0)  # Threshold
  }
}

rownames(image_matrix) <- colnames(image_matrix) <- c("Senior", "Mid", "Junior")

cat("Image Matrix (1 = consistent ties):\n")
print(image_matrix)

# Visualize network with position colors
V(g)$color <- c("red", "blue", "green")[true_positions]
V(g)$shape <- c("square", "circle", "triangle")[true_positions]

set.seed(42)
plot(g,
     vertex.size = 8,
     vertex.label = NA,
     edge.arrow.size = 0.3,
     edge.color = "gray80",
     main = "Organizational Network\nColored by Position")

legend("bottomleft",
       legend = c("Senior", "Mid", "Junior"),
       col = c("red", "blue", "green"),
       pch = c(15, 19, 17),
       bty = "n")


Interpretation: The image matrix reveals the deep structure - senior staff advise broadly, mid-level staff supervise juniors, and juniors report to mid-level staff. This pattern persists despite individual variation.


Real Network Example: Corporate Interlocks
Analyzing board membership as a bipartite network, then projecting to find structurally equivalent companies:


Code
library(igraph)
library(ggplot2)

# Simulate corporate board interlocks
# Companies share directors
set.seed(456)

n_companies <- 20
n_directors <- 40

# Bipartite network: companies and directors
# Create incidence matrix
B <- matrix(0, nrow = n_companies, ncol = n_directors)

# Core companies (well-connected)
for(i in 1:5) {
  B[i, sample(1:n_directors, 8)] <- 1
}

# Peripheral companies (few connections)
for(i in 6:20) {
  B[i, sample(1:n_directors, 3)] <- 1
}

# Project to company-company network (shared directors)
A <- B %*% t(B)
diag(A) <- 0

g <- graph_from_adjacency_matrix(A, mode = "undirected", weighted = TRUE)

# Calculate structural equivalence
# Companies are equivalent if they share the same directors
equivalence <- cor(t(B))  # Correlate director profiles
diag(equivalence) <- 0

# Hierarchical clustering
dist_matrix <- as.dist(1 - abs(equivalence))
hc <- hclust(dist_matrix, method = "ward.D2")

# Identify positions
positions <- cutree(hc, k = 3)
V(g)$position <- positions

# Visualize
V(g)$color <- c("coral", "lightblue", "lightgreen")[positions]
V(g)$size <- degree(g) * 2  # Size by degree

set.seed(42)
plot(g,
     vertex.label = NA,
     edge.width = sqrt(E(g)$weight),
     edge.color = "gray80",
     main = "Corporate Interlock Network\nColored by Position")

legend("bottomleft",
       legend = c("Core", "Semi-periphery", "Periphery"),
       col = c("coral", "lightblue", "lightgreen"),
       pch = 19,
       bty = "n")

cat("Position distribution:\n")
print(table(positions))

# Dendrogram
plot(hc, main = "Corporate Positions",
     xlab = "Company", ylab = "Distance")
rect.hclust(hc, k = 3, border = "red")


Findings: Core companies share many directors (high equivalence), forming an elite network. Peripheral companies have unique director profiles, indicating structural marginalisation.


CONCOR Algorithm
CONvergence of iterated CORrelations is a classical blockmodeling approach:

Calculate correlation matrix of node profiles
Re-correlate the correlation matrix
Iterate until convergence
Split network based on positive/negative correlations



Code
library(igraph)
library(sna)

# Simple CONCOR implementation
concor_split <- function(adj_matrix, max_iter = 25) {
  
  # Start with correlation matrix
  R <- cor(t(adj_matrix))
  
  # Iterate correlation
  for(i in 1:max_iter) {
    R_new <- cor(R)
    if(all(abs(R - R_new) < 0.001)) break
    R <- R_new
  }
  
  # Split based on first eigenvector
  partition <- ifelse(R[, 1] > 0, 1, 2)
  return(partition)
}

# Apply to karate club
karate <- make_graph("Zachary")
adj <- as.matrix(as_adjacency_matrix(karate))

partition <- concor_split(adj)

# Visualize
V(karate)$color <- c("coral", "lightblue")[partition]
set.seed(42)
plot(karate,
     vertex.size = 10,
     vertex.label.cex = 0.7,
     edge.color = "gray80",
     main = "CONCOR Partition of Karate Club")

cat("CONCOR detected", length(unique(partition)), "positions\n")
cat("Position sizes:", table(partition), "\n")


Why CONCOR works: Iterating correlations amplifies structural patterns. Nodes that have similar ties to similar alters cluster together.


Block Density Analysis
Assess blockmodel quality by comparing within-block vs.¬†between-block densities:


Code
library(igraph)

# Function to calculate block densities
block_densities <- function(adj_matrix, membership) {
  n_blocks <- max(membership)
  density_matrix <- matrix(0, nrow = n_blocks, ncol = n_blocks)
  
  for(i in 1:n_blocks) {
    for(j in 1:n_blocks) {
      block <- adj_matrix[membership == i, membership == j]
      density_matrix[i, j] <- mean(block)
    }
  }
  
  return(density_matrix)
}

# Apply to corporate network example
# (Using previous corporate interlocks data)
karate <- make_graph("Zachary")
adj <- as.matrix(as_adjacency_matrix(karate))

# Get positions from hierarchical clustering
equivalence <- cor(t(adj))
dist_matrix <- as.dist(1 - equivalence)
hc <- hclust(dist_matrix)
positions <- cutree(hc, k = 3)

# Calculate block densities
block_dens <- block_densities(adj, positions)
rownames(block_dens) <- colnames(block_dens) <- paste("Pos", 1:3)

cat("Block Density Matrix:\n")
print(round(block_dens, 3))

# Visualize as heatmap
library(ggplot2)
library(reshape2)

dens_long <- melt(block_dens)
colnames(dens_long) <- c("From", "To", "Density")

ggplot(dens_long, aes(x = From, y = To, fill = Density)) +
  geom_tile() +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(Density, 2)), color = "white", size = 5) +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "white", high = "darkblue") +
  labs(title = "Block Density Matrix",
       x = "To Position", y = "From Position") +
  theme_minimal() +
  coord_fixed()

# Quality metric: within vs. between density
within_density <- mean(diag(block_dens))
between_density <- mean(block_dens[row(block_dens) != col(block_dens)])

cat("\nBlockmodel Quality:\n")
cat("  Within-position density:", round(within_density, 3), "\n")
cat("  Between-position density:", round(between_density, 3), "\n")
cat("  Ratio (within/between):", round(within_density / between_density, 2), "\n")


Interpretation: Higher within/between ratio indicates clearer positional structure. Ratio > 2 suggests well-defined positions.

text:
Comparing Connectionist and Positional Approaches

When Communities ‚â† Positions
Communities and positions capture different aspects of structure. A key insight: structurally equivalent actors can be in different communities.


Code
library(igraph)
library(ggplot2)

# Create a network where communities ‚â† positions
# Two research groups (communities) with hierarchical roles (positions)
set.seed(789)

# Group 1: 5 PIs + 10 students
# Group 2: 5 PIs + 10 students
n <- 30

# Community membership (research groups)
community <- c(rep(1, 15), rep(2, 15))

# Position (PIs vs students)
position <- c(rep("PI", 5), rep("Student", 10),
              rep("PI", 5), rep("Student", 10))

# Generate network
g <- make_empty_graph(n, directed = FALSE)

# Within-group edges (communities)
for(grp in 1:2) {
  idx <- which(community == grp)
  g <- add_edges(g, t(combn(sample(idx, 10), 2)))
}

# PI-student mentorship (positions) - cross-community
for(i in which(position == "PI")) {
  students <- sample(which(position == "Student"), 3)
  g <- add_edges(g, rbind(rep(i, 3), students))
}

# Detect communities algorithmically
detected_comm <- cluster_louvain(g)

# Detect positions via equivalence
adj <- as.matrix(as_adjacency_matrix(g))
equiv <- cor(t(adj))
dist_mtx <- as.dist(1 - equiv)
hc <- hclust(dist_mtx)
detected_pos <- cutree(hc, k = 2)

# Cross-tabulation: communities vs positions
cat("Cross-tabulation: Detected Communities √ó Positions\n")
print(table(Community = membership(detected_comm), 
            Position = detected_pos))

cat("\nTrue Communities √ó True Positions\n")
print(table(Community = community, Position = position))

# Adjusted Rand Index: how much overlap?
ari_comm_pos <- compare(membership(detected_comm), detected_pos, 
                        method = "adjusted.rand")
cat("\nARI (Communities vs Positions):", round(ari_comm_pos, 3), "\n")
cat("Interpretation: ARI near 0 = orthogonal dimensions\n")

# Visualize both partitions
V(g)$comm_color <- c("red", "blue")[membership(detected_comm)]
V(g)$pos_shape <- c("circle", "square")[detected_pos]

par(mfrow = c(1, 2))
set.seed(42)
layout_coord <- layout_with_fr(g)

plot(g, layout = layout_coord,
     vertex.color = V(g)$comm_color,
     vertex.size = 8,
     vertex.label = NA,
     edge.color = "gray80",
     main = "Colored by Community")

plot(g, layout = layout_coord,
     vertex.shape = V(g)$pos_shape,
     vertex.color = "lightgray",
     vertex.size = 8,
     vertex.label = NA,
     edge.color = "gray80",
     main = "Shaped by Position")


Key finding: Low ARI indicates communities and positions are independent dimensions. A junior researcher in the ML group and a junior researcher in the theory group occupy the same position (advisee) in different communities.


Integration Analysis
When are communities and positions aligned vs.¬†orthogonal?

Aligned: Functional divisions (e.g., departments in a firm)
Orthogonal: Cross-cutting structures (e.g., seniority across departments)
Partially aligned: Complex reality (e.g., some senior staff bridge communities)



Code
library(igraph)

# Function to assess community-position integration
assess_integration <- function(graph) {
  
  # Detect communities
  comm <- cluster_louvain(graph)
  
  # Detect positions
  adj <- as.matrix(as_adjacency_matrix(graph))
  equiv <- cor(t(adj))
  dist_mtx <- as.dist(1 - equiv)
  hc <- hclust(dist_mtx)
  pos <- cutree(hc, k = length(comm))  # Same number for comparison
  
  # Calculate overlap metrics
  ari <- compare(membership(comm), pos, method = "adjusted.rand")
  nmi <- compare(membership(comm), pos, method = "nmi")
  
  list(
    ari = ari,
    nmi = nmi,
    interpretation = ifelse(
      ari > 0.7, "Strongly aligned",
      ifelse(ari > 0.3, "Partially aligned", "Orthogonal")
    )
  )
}

# Test on different network types
karate <- make_graph("Zachary")
result <- assess_integration(karate)

cat("Karate Club Integration:\n")
cat("  ARI:", round(result$ari, 3), "\n")
cat("  NMI:", round(result$nmi, 3), "\n")
cat("  Interpretation:", result$interpretation, "\n")

Granovetter: The Strength of Weak Ties
The Paradox

Strong ties cluster together (your friends know each other)
Weak ties bridge to distant parts of the network

Understanding Modularity
What is Modularity (Q)?
Measures if a partition has more within-group edges than expected by chance.
\[Q = \frac{1}{2m} \sum_{ij} \left[A_{ij} - \frac{k_i k_j}{2m}\right] \delta(c_i, c_j)\]

\(A_{ij}\) = observed edge
\(\frac{k_i k_j}{2m}\) = expected edge (null model)
\(\delta(c_i, c_j)\) = 1 if same community, 0 otherwise

Structural Equivalence: Definition
Two nodes are structurally equivalent if they have identical ties to the same alters
Example:

Node A connects to: {C, D, E}
Node B connects to: {C, D, E}
‚Üí A and B are structurally equivalent

Implication: They are substitutable - occupy the same position

title: Communities, Roles, and Positions in Networks
text:
Types of Equivalence
1. Structural Equivalence (Strict) - Two nodes are connected to the exact same other nodes. - Example: Two siblings who have the exact same parents and grandparents. - Business: Two customer service reps who handle the exact same set of tickets (rare).
2. Regular Equivalence (Functional) - Two nodes are connected to equivalent types of nodes. - Example: Two doctors. Dr.¬†A treats Patient X; Dr.¬†B treats Patient Y. They don‚Äôt know the same people, but they have the same relationship to their patients. - Business: Two department heads. They manage different teams, but structurally they are identical.
We typically use Structural Equivalence (via correlation) as a proxy for Regular Equivalence in dense networks.

title: Communities, Roles, and Positions in Networks
text:
Measuring Structural Equivalence
The Method: Use correlation to measure how similar two nodes‚Äô tie patterns are.

High correlation (‚Üí 1): Nodes connect to the same others ‚Üí Structurally equivalent
Low correlation (‚Üí 0 or negative): Nodes have different tie patterns ‚Üí Different positions

Example Network: 4 nodes with directed ties







Interpretation



Nodes A & B: Correlation ‚âà 1.0 ‚Üí Highly equivalent (both connect to B, C)
Nodes C & D: Correlation ‚âà 1.0 ‚Üí Highly equivalent (both connect to C)
Nodes A & C: Correlation ‚âà 0 ‚Üí Not equivalent (different tie patterns)

Conclusion: We can group {A, B} into one position and {C, D} into another.

title: Communities, Roles, and Positions in Networks
text:
Durkheim‚Äôs Theory & Network Analysis
Sociologist √âmile Durkheim proposed two forms of social integration that map perfectly onto network analysis:
1. Mechanical Solidarity (Cohesion)

Integration through similarity and direct interaction.
‚ÄúWe are connected because we are the same.‚Äù
Network Concept: Communities (Clusters, Cliques).

2. Organic Solidarity (Equivalence)

Integration through interdependence and specialized roles.
‚ÄúWe are connected because we need each other‚Äôs different functions.‚Äù
Network Concept: Positions (Roles, Blockmodels).

Key Insight: A network can be analyzed through cohesion (who hangs out with whom) or equivalence (who does the same job).

title: Communities, Roles, and Positions in Networks
text:
The ‚ÄúSmall World‚Äù Phenomenon
The Concept
Most real-world networks (social, biological, technological) exhibit the ‚ÄúSmall World‚Äù property:

High Clustering: My friends are likely to be friends with each other (like a caveman village).
Short Path Lengths: I can reach anyone in the world in ~6 steps (like a random graph).

Why?

Homophily creates the clusters (local cohesion).
Weak Ties (bridges) create the shortcuts (global reach).

Business Implication

Information Diffusion: News travels fast in small worlds.
Viral Marketing: You need to seed ideas in different clusters (high clustering) but ensure they can jump across bridges (short paths).

title: Communities, Roles, and Positions in Networks
text:
Understanding Modularity (Q)
Many of the community detection algorithms we just discussed, such as Louvain, aim to optimize a metric called Modularity (Q).
The Metric
Modularity measures the strength of division of a network into modules (communities).
\[Q = \text{(Fraction of edges within groups)} - \text{(Expected fraction if edges were random)}\]
Interpretation

\(Q \approx 0\): The network is random; no community structure.
\(Q \in [0.3, 0.7]\): Strong community structure (common in social networks).
\(Q \to 1\): Disconnected components (islands).

The ‚ÄúResolution Limit‚Äù

Modularity optimization has a blind spot: it may fail to detect small communities in very large networks, merging them into larger clusters.
Solution: Use multi-resolution algorithms (e.g., Louvain with resolution parameter).

Definitions: Role vs.¬†Position
Role

A pattern of relationships.

Abstract concept.

Position

Equivalence ` - The mathematical rule we use to decide if two nodes are in the same position.

title: Communities, Roles, and Positions in Networks
text:
Blockmodeling: The Strategic Map
Blockmodeling is the process of reducing a complex network into a simplified ‚ÄúImage Matrix‚Äù based on positions.
Process: 1. Partition actors into positions (using clustering/CONCOR). 2. Calculate Density between all pairs of positions. 3. Threshold to create binary Image Matrix (1 if density > cutoff, else 0).
Example Image Matrix (Core-Periphery)
          Core   Periphery
Core      [ 1       1    ]  <-- Core talks to Core AND Periphery
Periphery [ 1       0    ]  <-- Periphery talks to Core but NOT each other
Interpretation: A centralized system where the Core coordinates everything.

Final Thought: A complete network analysis usually requires both. You want to know who is in the ‚ÄúMarketing Cluster‚Äù (Community) AND who is the ‚ÄúBridge‚Äù (Role) within that cluster.

Why Do Networks Are More Than the Sum of Their Parts?
Sociologist √âmile Durkheim proposed two forms of social integration that map perfectly onto network analysis, and explain why networks are more than the sum of their parts:



1. Mechanical Solidarity (Cohesion)



Integration through similarity and direct interaction.
‚ÄúWe are connected because we are the same.‚Äù
Network Concept: Communities (Clusters, Cliques).







2. Organic Solidarity (Equivalence)



Integration through interdependence and specialized roles.
‚ÄúWe are connected because we need each other‚Äôs different functions.‚Äù
Network Concept: Positions (Roles, Blockmodels).




Key Insight: A network can be analyzed through cohesion (who hangs out with whom) or equivalence (who does the same job).

title: Communities, Roles, and Positions in Networks
text:
Strong Communities: The Clique
Definition A Clique is a subgraph where every distinct pair of nodes is adjacent. It represents the strictest form of cohesion.

title: Communities, Roles, and Positions in Networks
text:
Weak Communities: Density-Based
Definition A Weak Community is a subgraph where the density of internal edges is significantly higher than the density of external edges (ties to the rest of the network).

title: Communities, Roles, and Positions in Networks
text:
LS Sets: Robustness
Definition An LS Set is a subset of nodes where any proper subset has more ties to the rest of the group than to the outside. It represents defensive cohesion‚Äîit is harder to split the group than to disconnect it from the network.

Advanced Position Analysis: Beyond Simple Equivalence
While structural equivalence focuses on identical tie patterns, real-world position analysis often requires more sophisticated approaches:



Triad Census: Micro-Structural Signatures


What it is: Analyzing the frequency of different triad configurations (3-node subgraphs) around each actor.
Why it matters: Actors in the same position tend to participate in similar types of triads.
Example: - Brokers appear in many ‚Äúopen triads‚Äù (A‚ÜíB‚ÜíC, but no A‚ÜíC) - Core members appear in many ‚Äúclosed triads‚Äù (A‚ÜîÔ∏éB‚ÜîÔ∏éC‚ÜîÔ∏éA)
Business Application: In organizational networks, managers who participate in similar triad patterns likely have similar coordination roles, even if they manage different teams.






Multiplexity: Multi-Dimensional Roles


What it is: Positions defined across multiple relationship types simultaneously.
Why it matters: Real roles are rarely defined by a single tie type.
Example: A ‚Äútrusted advisor‚Äù position might require both: - High expertise ties (people seek their advice) - High friendship ties (people trust them personally)
Business Application: In innovation networks, successful ‚Äúinnovation champions‚Äù often occupy positions with both formal authority ties AND informal collaboration ties.
